projects.name: Travel Allocation of Multiple Student Groups in Paris
projects.subtitle: A prototype interface for visualizing how Mobi's algorithm builds itineraries for groups of students in Paris.
projects.description: An interactive visualization prototype that visualizes how our constraint programming algorithm can allocate and distribute student groups across multiple days in Paris. The design shows the different scenarios, how Mobi's algorithm meets the constraints and the itineraries along a week travel.

projects.name: Global Disasters 1989-2018
projects.subtitle: Visualizing the density and impact of natural disasters and conflicts around the world over time.
projects.description: Mobi has begun to collaborate with non-profit organizations for disaster response to help with the planning. This visualization was one of our first attempts to overlay the global disasters and conflicts and get a first view of their impact our the world. Using a hexagonal grid, the map visualizes the disasters and conflicts aggregated by hexagon cell and by date.

projects.name: Climate Data in Travel Exploration
projects.subtitle: A storytelling example of how Mobi in incorporating temporal climate parameters in offering travel plans.
projects.description: An interactive visualization that tells the story of how we use climate data layers to showcase the exploratory process of selecting a destination to visit and explore coral reefs.

projects.name: Global Region Ranking by User Preferences
projects.subtitle: An internal data visualization tool for data exploration
projects.description: This is a first prototype of an internal data visualization tool for Mobi's research scientists. The interface allows the user to filter the dataset by selecting tags of their preferences and retrieve the highest scored h3 cells globally.

projects.name: Multimodal Learning
projects.subtitle: Project in Deep Learning Seminar
projects.description: This project was developed as part of my final project for the Fall 2021 Deep Learning class that I took at MIT. I developed an interactive data visualization for A.Owens and A.Efros(2018) paper on audio-visual scene analysis. I experimented and tested their model on different inputs from the Google AudioSet and produced a blog to bring new insight and help explain the proposed machine learning model.

projects.name: Soundscapes as Urban Transformation
projects.subtitle: Introducing a notational language that represents the shifting relationships between sound, space, and movement
projects.description: Research project (thesis) with committee: Terry Knight, George Stiny, Arvind Satyanarayan, and Andres Sevtsuk. Studied the impact of COVID-19 on urban environments through sound. Analyzed audio & geospatial data to extract geo-sound clusters using Python, Machine Learning (Scikit-learn), UMAP & Matplotlib. Developed a notational language to visualize urban sound clusters & prototyped an interactive web interface using Javascript, D3 & WebGL

projects.name: Urban Transformations in Istanbul : The Fener-Balat Grammar
projects.subtitle: Diploma Thesis | National Technical University of Athens
projects.description: The suburbs Fener and Balat in Istanbul, Turkey are part of the greater metropolitan district of the city. Since 1887, Fener and Balat have gone through a series of dynamic urban transformations not resulting from methodical planning.

projects.name: School of Unknownables
projects.subtitle: Istanbul Design Biennal
projects.description: How do you know a place? What do you know of a place and through whom? What remains unknown? How does knowing and unknowing practices relate to owning, caring about, and sharing place? Our A School of Schools investigates what it means to ‘know’ a place, both as an individual and collectively, as a ‘professional’ and a ‘non-professional’, as an educator and a learner, and explores alternative educational practices in order to question the existing power structures, and sets out to stimulate more egalitarian relationships amongst the different agents of a place. Knowledge is often instrumentalized as a hegemonic device and suggests hierarchies between things like important and secondary, and consequently frames what is to be considered central and marginal. Our school aims to reframe the dominant knowledge of a place as one of the multiple knowledges of that place. We question the ‘well-known’ history and facts of a place and start by un-knowing and un-fixing the established information about a place and search for the lesser- known stories and experiences, that may be subtle or marginal, and most importantly we seek to acknowledge the unrevealed layers of ‘other knowledges’. It is about accepting our own social positions and the limits of our knowledge and facing the fact that we can only ascertain certain things about a place and that the major part will always remain unknowable. Today, more and more, we are faced with highly institutionalized educational environments, where educators and learners are assessed by quantitative rather than qualitative criteria. This kind of approach results in more isolated educational practices in design schools, which lose touch with the socio-cultural context. Extensive production over a short period of time is required by the new world order, mass production and consumption cycles rule. As a consequence, designers in practice and education alike are detached from the site, the users and the inhabitants; merely superficial authoritative knowledge is believed to be sufficient when deciding about the future of a place. The school of unknowables aims to step back from the all-knowing stance, and rather develop sensitive and multiple relationships with place, inhabitants and stories, weaving fine threads across the subtle urban fabrics.

projects.name: Exploring Data Visually
projects.subtitle: Sketching Visualizations for Diverse Audiences
projects.description: I was invited to teach a workshop on Exploratory Visual Analysis in the Information Design Studio I, which is a studio required for first-year master's student in the Information Design and Data Visualization program at Northeastern University. The workshop consisted of two parts to sequentially build on skills developed and practiced from the first to the last session. The workshop focused on the creative, iterative process of visual data exploration, emphasizing the reasoning behind design decisions and the role of the audience in this process. These skills are integral to the data visualization practice but are often overlooked in favor of creating polished designs. As an outcome, students practiced skills in creative critical thinking, tailored their designs to target audiences, and learned to conduct research through visual exploration.
